ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

"COURTESY AND SERVICE"
COURSES FOR HOSPITAL STAFF


    1. Mrs C. V. Devan Nair asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider holding "Courtesy and Service" courses for members of hospital staff to improve their relations with the public.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. Government places great importance in improving courtesy and service to the public by its Government servants. At the end of 1960, a Committee consisting of ministerial and departmental representatives drew up a blue-print for improvements in the relationship between the Government and the public. `This was followed by an intensive campaign in each Ministry to improve en courtesy and service. Courtesy officers were appointed in each section of the Ministry. Staff were briefed on the importance of courtesy. Talks were given to staff dealing with the public, such as telephone operators, medical and health servants, nurses and doctors. The co-operation of the unions was also sought in these efforts. In addition, the Central Complaints Bureau was established.

    Formal courtesy and service courses are not at present being conducted for hospital staff, and I do not think it necessary to conduct courtesy and service courses as suggested by the hon. Member for Moulmein, because adequate measures have already been taken to ensure that all staff are expected to show maximum possible courtesy and civility to the public. Nurses are being taught ethics in their training courses, and medical health servants are briefed on the importance of courtesy and service on appointment.

    Besides, under the Public Service (Disciplinary Proceedings - Delegation of Functions) Regulations, 1962, published in the Government Gazette Supplement No. 139 dated 20th July, 1962, Regulation 4 provides, inter alia, that any officer found guilty of being rude to (the public in speech: or being discourteous to the public in manner, shall

Column: 428

be liable to be punished under regulations 6, 7 and 8 thereof.

    Depending upon the gravity of the offence, the latter regulations provide:

    (a) that such officer be severely reprimanded and a record made of the reprimand in his Record of Service; or

    (b) . . . forfeiture of not more than one-half of such officer's basic monthly salary or by a fine of two hundred dollars whichever is the less; or

    (c) stoppage or deferment of any increment of salary; or

    (d) discontinuance of his further service.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Will the Minister concerned tell this House whether there is any Complaints Bureau accessible to patients to make complaints to the officers in the hospital about their grievances?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to remind the hon. Member for Bras Basah that there is already in existence a Central Complaints Bureau, and all that a member of the public need do is to write a letter direct to me and it will be investigated.

RENT INCREASE BY LANDLORDS ON BUILDINGS BUILT AFTER 1947


    2. Mrs C. V. Devan Nair asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether he will take measures to prevent landlords from increasing rents on buildings built after 1947 which do not come within the provisions of the Rent Control Ordinance.

    The Minister for Law (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, to extend the provisions of the Rent Control Ordinance to cover new buildings may well discourage private building and development which the Government wishes to encourage. The solution lies in increasing the availability of accommodation.

Column: 428

REPAIRS AND REWIRING OF
PREMISES BY LANDLORDS


    3. Mrs C. V. Devan Nair asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether he will consider introducing amending legislation to provide for repairs and rewiring of premises to be effected by landlords.

Column: 429



    The Minister for Law (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the obligation on the part of a landlord to carry out repairs and rewiring of premises is governed by the terms of the contract of lease or tenancy between the landlord and the tenant. In the absence of an express clause, the landlord should undertake major repairs and the tenant minor repairs.

    My Ministry will look into the matter in order to ascertain whether such legislation is feasible or practical.

ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE
FOR 1965


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.40 p.m.

    The Chairman: Estimates of Expenditure of the State of Singapore for the year 1965, as contained in Paper Cmd. 24 of 1964. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure on page 39 of the Paper.

    Dealing now with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement :-

Column: 429

Head 0103 -

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0103 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 3002.*
*The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Lim Huan Boon.


    This is on the production of the Legislative Assembly Hansards. We find that the vote provided for next year has been reduced to a great extent, namely, from $33,780 to $22,000. It seems to me that every year the vote provided for the production of the Legislative Assembly Hansards has been reduced .1 would like to ask the Minister responsible whether he can give any explanation on this matter.

Column: 430



    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, the reduction in the provision made for the production of the Assembly Hansards is in anticipation that there will not be so many night sittings of this Assembly to warrant overtime payments. In 1961 there were 41 Assembly sittings; 34 in 1962 and 32 in 1963. The provision of $22,000 for 1965 is estimated to cover overtime payments and remuneration for about 30 sittings.

    The Chairman: Does the Member wish to withdraw his amendment, or does he want the House to vote on it?

    Mr Chia Thye Poh: I withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $686,070 for Head 0103 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 430



    Head 0104 -

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $100.+
+The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Lim Huan Boon.


    Sir, we find that under this head there are several items of expenditure concerned with students in higher institutions of learning, for example, items of expenditure relating to bursaries, scholarships and allowances. The Government has announced that it will provide bursaries and financial assistance to poor students entering these institutions of higher learning to help them to continue with their studies. Sir, superficially these promises sound very nice. But we have found that the Government has been making use of these bursaries under this Head to achieve the P.A.P.'s own selfish interest.

2.45 p.m.

    We know that before a bursary is issued, all students will have to apply for it, and the Government will have to carry out an investigation which will take a long period of time. Of course, in the course of investigation, political factors will be involved. Perhaps certain students not liked by the Government will not be able to get the bursaries. But even after getting the bursaries, these

Column: 431

may be cancelled. There is a recent case of a particular student's bursary being cancelled. The Government has also cancelled the bursaries of quite a good number of Nantah students whose conduct and academic merits have been very good. These students have not been found to be deficient in their studies; nor has there been any blemish on their character. So the abolition of their bursaries can be attributed to the Govern ment's political prejudices. Such actions by the Government undoubtedly can be construed as extorting funds from the public and misusing them. We know that in the past, the Government tried to split the student bodies in the universities. Bursaries were also used as a means to achieve that purpose. For instance, the Government could resort to getting the help of the P.A.P. elements in the institutions to propagate the line that if the students did not vote for their man, the P.A.P. man, then their bursaries would be cancelled. Such things did happen before in the past. This has happened in Nanyang University and also in the University of Singapore. Therefore, we say that the true intention of the Government is to misuse public funds to carry out its open corruption. I will also raise another matter.

    During August to September this year, the Public Service Commission wrote to the Ministry of Education in Japan to cancel the bursary of a student who was the Chairman of the Malayan Students Committee in Japan. Chua Swee Lin was the person who got a Japanese scholarship amounting to $200 Malayan money per month in 1962 to learn ship-building. Because the students' union there expressed their dissatisfaction with Malaysia, the Government therefore took suppressive action against the student there, and tried to resort to the cancellation of the bursary through the Japanese Government to achieve its purpose. Such action by the Government -

    The Chairman: Order. I think the Member should confine himself, while he is on this particular item, to matters which are within the power of the Public Service Commission. It may well be that

Column: 432

the recall of the student is not within the powers of the Public Service Commission.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this action of the Government has been carried out through the Public Service Commission. It was the Public Service Commission that wrote to the Japanese Government to cancel the bursary of this particular student. That is why I have mentioned this.

    I also want to talk about certain matters relating to Government departments. If graduates want to join the Government service so that they can teach, they have to go through a selection procedure by way of interview by the Public Service Commission. Many teachers in aided secondary schools applied to the Public Service Commission for confirmation of their jobs after a period of time, and they had their applications refused. In other words, their applications to continue to teach in the schools were refused. I understand that many of these graduate teachers were not taken to be incapable or inefficient in their teaching. The fact is that the Public Service Commission, during their investigations, received certain information from the Special Branch. I would like to ask, where is the value of the Public Service Commission if they have to listen to and be subjected to interference from the Special Branch? If that is the case, then let the Special Branch take over their functions.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Jurong began with some very nasty allegations that scholar-ships are awarded on the basis of political patronage and political chicanery. But he ended on a more realistic note. I reject both the scurrilous allegations that the P.S.C. in fact carries out the instructions of the Special Branch, and, therefore, it is best that the Special Branch were to substitute itself for the P.S.C.

    The purpose of these scholarships now appearing under the Head of Public Service Commission is to centralise and co-ordinate the award of

Column: 433

scholarships in such a way as to meet the requirements of the State; the Finance Ministry, the Economic Development Division, the Education Ministry. Awards are given to persons on the basis of merit, not whether they are pro or against any political Party. But where a person is deemed a security risk to the State, where his political beliefs are of such a nature as to constitute a risk, then it is not the business of the State to give money to such people in order to help them undermine the State. But these policies are interpreted very liberally. Let me explain that the Member for Tampines was in receipt of a bursary under the P.A.P. Government whilst he was at the University of Nanyang. We are fairly wide and flexible. We do not want to make a man more embittered and more frustrated with society than he need be. If he has youthful inclinations towards extreme political views, well, by all means, let him go through that phase; let him mature. But when we know a man is already committed to the destruction of the democratic State, it is not our business to spend money on him to equip him to carry out his purposes better.

    However, Mr Speaker, Sir, this problem will arise on less and less occasions in the future, because, as the Member now knows, there is the Internal Security Act which makes it necessary for a student to be security cleared first before he is admitted to a university.

    As for the other allegation that the Public Service Commission wrote to the Japanese Government to cancel a scholarship given to a particular student, that is not within my knowledge. I do not think the Public Service Commission did any such thing. It is not in a position to communicate with any foreign Government. The only Ministry which now communicates with foreign Governments is the External Affairs Ministry in Kuala Lumpur. I do not even know whether it did or not. I should not assume, as the Member for Jurong did, that one student is so very important as to warrant the intervention of the External Affairs Ministry. I should not be the least bit surprised that the student brought it

Column: 434

upon himself by his foolish activities in Japan which came to the notice of the Japanese Government.

    Finally, the selection of officers by the P.S.C. for appointments into the administrative or the education service. Here again, as I have said, it is not the business of the Government to appoint people either into the administrative or the educational service to breed more disaffection and disloyalty, not to a particular political Party or to a parti cular government of Singapore, but to the whole institution of the State, to the whole concept of the democratic State. Here again it is a policy which has to be implemented with a great deal of sensitivity. One of the points the Public Service Commission must consider is the security risk a particular person may carry with him into the administration; information which comes from the Intelligence organs of the Government, now the Central Government.

3.00 p.m.

    We have to weigh whether a man is really committed, or it is not better to give him a chance and a way out, to let him find fulfilment in fruitful, constructive work, than to throw that away out of sheer frustration and bitterness. It is a fine balance. We do not want to make more people look more haggard, more hard, and more bitter day by day, as the Member for Jurong and his colleagues do. Over the last one year, trouble upon trouble has fallen upon his shoulders - very youthful shoulders, Mr Speaker, Sir. First, it was the Member for Bukit Merah who was leading the charge of the light brigade (a very light brigade this one). The Member for Bukit Merah, being a much more cir cumspect, equable type, decided that this was a mug's game, if I may say so, and has opted out from the leadership.

    Well, Mr Speaker, Sir, -

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I doubt if the remarks made by the Prime Minister have any relevance to this issue.

    The Chairman: Perhaps the Prime Minister will come back to the amendment.

Column: 435



    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): I know it hurts, Mr Speaker, Sir. But the point I want to make is this: we do not want to have more bitter people in this world. If we can give them jobs, give them scholarships, and give them fulfilment, we will. But when we know that the man is so embittered as to bring the State down, then I say it is the business of the P.S.C. and let me inform the Member for Jurong that usually the P.S.C. takes a lenient view and gives the man a chance. But when he turns out to be a security risk, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, on my advice, intervenes.

    If we are foolish in the implementation of these scholarships, and giving of jobs, and if we are insensitive and crude, we drive more people to bitterness and to opposition. That is not our job, that is not our intention, and that is not in our interests. We want to give all those who desire to contribute to the welfare and well-being of our country an opportunity to play their role. It is not too late even for Members on the other side to rethink their positions in these very changed circumstances.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been listening carefully to the Prime Minister's reply to the query raised by my colleague.

    In regard to the administration of bursaries and scholarships which he relates closely to the security risk of a certain student, I have this doubt, Mr Speaker. What is the criterion by which students may be judged with regard to the so-called security risk?

    The question also arises: those students receiving bursaries who refuse to become tools of the P.A.P., or who refuse to be made use of by the P.A.P., or who do not endorse the policies of the P.A.P. - are they to be regarded as security risks?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, I could have saved a lot of trouble if I had explained further. These security objections are not objections taken by the Government. It is done by a proper Intelligence agency. It is now, in fact, not a State Government responsibility. Security Intelligence is placed before the

Column: 436

P.S.C. in the making of appointments or in the dispensation of scholarships, it has nothing to do with political party affiliations. I think the Member may be under some misapprehension that it is either because the man is pro-P.A.P., or pro-Alliance, or pro-Barisan. That has got nothing to do with it, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I would like to say this, that Singapore is still under colonial rule or neo-colonial rule. Take, for example, a student of Nantah or the Singapore University or the Singapore Polytechnic, if he is against imperialism, i.e. if he is against the British masters, then will the P.S.C. refuse to give him a bursary or a scholarship? We can give several interpretations of his behaviour. Those who are in actual control have absolute power at any time over all the departments under their control.

    I would also like to raise one other point with regard to bursaries. The administration of bursaries is not aimed at fostering talent in our country. Why should I say this? I say this because I have come across some highly talented students who have been denied the opportunity of having bursaries or scholar ships. Furthermore, because of their family circumstances, these highly talented students cannot afford to go for further studies. I would have thought that bursaries would have been awarded purely on the basis of academic standards and financial difficulties of the students. But the Government is not helping these people who deserve bursaries. As far as I know, the P.A.P.'s idea is to give bursaries to some students who are not so highly talented and who are not so poorly off. I, in the Opposition, have the responsibility to express the view that the Government should be urged to note the facts that I have raised - that the allocation of bursaries should not be based purely on security grounds alone, because this should not be the case.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Jalan Kayu can give me any specific instance where he thinks an award of a scholarship or a

Column: 437

bursary has been granted not in accordance with merit and need, I shall certainly have the matter investigated.

    I would like to tell him that there .are two forms of scholarships and bursaries. One is on the basis of competitive merit, regardless of the financial circumstances of the family; competitive merit and performance entitles the student to a scholarship. The other comes under the classification of bur saries and other assistance. This is related to the question of need - first, that the student is worth assisting; and second, that the student is in need of assistance. If the Member will supply me with any information - as he says he has knowledge of irregularity or improper award - I shall have the matter properly investigated. And I am quite prepared to place the result of any such investigation into his complaint before this House, or otherwise make it public. I think it is important that in the process of wanting to score political points, one should not spread a big smear that scholarships, appointments to the State, the whole works is just one bag of tricks meant to patronise friends, supporters, carpet-baggers. If the State is to survive, it must stand strict scrutiny. If the democratic system of one man one vote and open criticism is to survive, it must withstand criticism such as has been made in a veiled and vague manner by the Member for Jurong and the Member for Jalan Kayu. I say: make your specific charges, list them, and we will investigate them and place the results before this Assembly. But I say this, that first we accept the position that nobody is entitled as of right to ask, if the State helps him, to dismantle the democratic system. That is not the purpose of this Government or the P.S.C. or any of the other institutions of state.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister has said just now that the information was from an Intelligence source. I -

    The Prime Minister: On a point of order. I do not want to be misquoted. I have never said "informers" (ching pao jen). What I said was "security

Column: 438

assessment by the Special Branch". We do not have any informers.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, so let it be Intelligence investigation. The so-called Intelligence investigation should be revealed in this House.

    I now want to talk about bursaries. At the present moment, the payment of bursaries in the State is intended to help poor students to pursue higher education. But this aid does not exist any more because the payment of bursaries has become a tool of the P.A.P. The administration of bursaries is virtually under the control of the P.A.P. so that the disciples of the P.A.P. and their supporters may be gathered together to help them during the elections and to contribute to the Party funds. If you want to get this bursary, then you must toe the line of the P.A.P. This is the present situation.

    The Prime Minister says that these bursaries are not given casually but are given according to certain rules, and to the financial circumstances of the applicants. If this is so, then it is strange that when an undergraduate, who is considered poor and receives a bursary for the first, second and third years, and in the fourth year - when he is still poor - he is all of a sudden recalled. Does it mean that all of a sudden his family has become so well off that he does not deserve any more help? This is strange. This is done according to the Intelligence given by the Special Branch which is virtually under the control of the British.

    I say that at the present moment those recipients of bursaries are under certain restrictions. They run the risk of having their bursaries withdrawn. If they cannot afford to go on without bursaries, they have to work part-time in order to carry on their studies. They cannot enjoy life so comfortably as the Ministers can. And if the students refuse to be suppressed by the Government, then they have to work extra hard to earn money to finance their studies.

3.15 p.m.

    The Government is now extensively suppressing the students. In the past few

Column: 439

years, we have seen that many students and graduates have been unable to get jobs from the Government. The Government is not in any position to give them jobs - particularly to Nanyang University graduates. I who have been a Nantah student know that there were many recipients of bursaries, hut now the number has been reduced in spite of the fact that many of them are deserving of bursaries. Some graduates who have passed out are unemployed. So the granting of bursaries is a means by which the Government tries to oppress tbe Nanyang under-graduates and graduates. Those who have passed out are unable to get jobs and tbe Government is not giving them any help; no outlet is provided for them. I who have been a recipient of some aid from the Government - [Interruption]. I who have been a recipient of some aid from the Government, together with other recipients of bursaries, know that we have not been accepted into the public service. I myself have not been taken into the Government. On the other hand, we see that the Deputy Prime Minister is a teacher and a Member of the Assembly at the same time. The P.S.C. has made a ruling that teachers of government-aided schools cannot undertake any extra work. The ruling is that extra-mural activities should be controlled. This adversely affects the under-graduates because if they want to do anything outside their studies, they will be interfered with by the Government: there will be a lot of restrictions on their behaviour. When they are dissatisfied with the Government, they run the risk of losing their bursaries.

    The regulations governing the granting of bursaries are unreasonable. When the under-graduates discover this fact, they air their grievances before the Minister for Education. Certain claims are made to revise the existing regulations, but in spite of repeated requests and discussions, the Government refuses to revise them. So the students have no alternative but to accept these stringent regulations. These regulations have been used by the P.A.P. Government to oppress the undergraduates of Nanyang University.

Column: 440



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. want recipients of bursaries to give information on others who have acted or said anything against them. So the P.A.P. are making use of bursaries to help the Special Branch to oppress students. We oppose the abuse of such funds.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister has said just now that if we could give him specific cases of misuse of bursaries by some students, he would deal with them accordingly. I would like to tell you, Mr Speaker, Sir, that this statement made by the Prime Minister is an attempt to shirk his responsibility as the head of the Government. If the whole ruling machinery with a force of thou sands of civil servants are not aware of this fact, then it is very sad. The administration of bursaries is not well done. This is not admitted by the Government and it tries to shirk its responsibility. It is a fact that public funds have been abused and misused.

    I have to say some more on this. I have been given to understand by my friends who applied for bursaries that during the interview, questions were fired at them at random and they were made fun of. One question asked of these students was, "Have you ever been in love?" [Interruption in Mandarin by the Prime Minister] You know it too well. If you do not believe it, ask your informers!

    The Chairman: Order. If the Member is talking about the Prime Minister, he must say, "The Prime Minister knows it too well."

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, we can imagine how improper it is that bursaries are thus awarded!

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have a suggestion to make: every citizen of Singapore is duty bound to pay taxes and if a person is against colonial rule or imperialism, tben no matter whether he is pro-P.A.P. or pro-Barisan, he should be treated in the same way as the others. There should be equal treatment all round. My colleague has said that he was the recipient of a bursary, but he was not taken into the

Column: 441

Government service because of his political affiliation. But if he had wanted to be as servile as the others, he would have been taken in.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, out of all these scurrilous charges have come two specific instances - the Member for Tampines himself when he compared his unfortunate position or his unfavour able treatment with that of the Deputy Prime Minister.

    Sir, I have already explained why, in spite of his undesirable political associates, we allowed him a bursary in Nanyang University. It was the policy of the Government that so long as a man is redeemable - in his case, I would not write him off as already lost - he will be given a chance. Unfortunately, Mr Speaker, Sir, he failed. He had to be referred for an extra year and ultimately he passed. He now says that we have not given him a job, unlike the Deputy Prime Minister who is not only in office as a Minister but is also teaching. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is quite different. The University is an autonomous body; it is not a Government institution. The Deputy Prime Minister asked that he be allowed to continue the direction of scholars whose research he was supervising and to give his lectures to keep his knowledge up to date. The Member for Tampines is asking for a Government appointment and it is against the Constitution for a Government servant to be a Member of the Assembly or vice versa. If we allow him to become a member of the public service, we will be doing him a disservice, because automatically he will be disqualified from sitting in this Chamber and then he will say what a lot of wicked people we are for disqualifying him. But let me tell him this. Any man worth his weight does not have to get a job in the Government service to make his living.

    Let me tell him this further point, that in a number of so-called socialist countries, a man who is against the State, who is against the Russian Government, the Chinese Government or the Polish Government, not only does not get a scholarship, but he does not even get

Column: 442
